question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
I have seen / a movie / on schooling / yesterday.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 11_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: (3) I have seen
Solution:
• The phrase "yesterday" indicates a specific time in the past.
• When a specific past time is mentioned, the past simple tense should be used, not the present perfect.
• So, instead of "I have seen," the correct phrase is "I saw."
• Other parts (a movie, on schooling, yesterday) are correct.
• Therefore, segment (3) contains the error.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The policeman asked / many people but / no one was knowing / how the accident happened.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 12 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

The phrase “was knowing” is grammatically incorrect because:

  • The verb “know” is a stative verb, not an action verb.

  • Stative verbs describe a state (like knowing, liking, believing) and are not used in continuous tenses (was knowing, is knowing, etc.).

✅ Correct Usage:

  • ❌ was knowing

  • ✅ knew

Part of Speech with the Error:

Verb tense – incorrect use of past continuous with a stative verb.

Correct Sentence:

“The policeman asked many people but no one knew how the accident happened.”

✔️ Correct Answer: no one was knowing

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The audience has being / angry as the magician / is not performing / as expected.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 12 Dec Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: The audience has being

Explanation:
In English, the present perfect requires the auxiliary has (or have) + been (past participle), not being. Here the correct form is “The audience has been angry…,” so “has being” is ungrammatical.

  • Error:has being → has been rest of the sentence is correct.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
It takes me an hour / to get to work at the moment, / but when the new road is finished, / it be much quicker.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-1 (9_00 to 11_00 AM))
option_1: it takes me an hour
option_2: but when the new road is finished
option_4: to get to work at the moment
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: It be much quicker

The error is in the segment: "it be much quicker." The verb "be" is not conjugated correctly. In English, when talking about future events, we typically use the auxiliary verb "will" to indicate the future tense. Therefore, the corrected form should be: "but when the new road is finished, it will be much quicker."

The corrected sentence is: "It takes me an hour to get to work at the moment, but when the new road is finished, it will be much quicker."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
I have never played a hero before, so I jump at the chance.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-3 4_30 PM - 6_30 PM)
option_1: So I jump at the chance
solution:
Answer: a) So I jump at the chance

Explanation:
The sentence starts in present perfect tense ("I have never played"), so the second part should maintain the same tense.
But "I jump" is in simple present, which creates a tense mismatch.

  • It should be: "I jumped at the chance" to match the past context.

  • Correct sentence: I have never played a hero before, so I jumped at the chance.

Error: Tense inconsistency between parts.
Corrected Part: So I jumped at the chance.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
The fight of the cobra and the mongoose / is a classic drama often seen in India, / and the outcome was largely the same.

option_2: is a classic drama often seen in India

solution:

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
W̲h̲e̲n̲ I b̲o̲u̲g̲h̲t̲ the book, I t̲h̲o̲u̲g̲h̲t̲ it w̲i̲l̲l̲ be interesting.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 12_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
The error in this sentence is the use of "will." The past tense of "will" is "would." When narrating an action that occurred in the past, the correct form is to use "would" instead of "will." Therefore, the corrected sentence would be:

"When I b̲o̲u̲g̲h̲t̲ the book, I t̲h̲o̲u̲g̲h̲t̲ it w̲o̲u̲l̲d̲ be interesting."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
My teacher told me that / all that / glitters was not gold.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 12_Sept_Shift-2)
option_1: My teacher told me that
solution:
he corrected sentence should be:

"My teacher told me that / all that / glitters is not gold."

The phrase "all that glitters is not gold" is a well-known proverb, meaning that not everything that appears valuable or attractive is actually valuable or genuine. In the original sentence, the word "was" is incorrect because the proverb is stating a general truth or principle, and the correct verb form to use is "is."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four parts. Identify the part that contains an error.
(A) It is a / (B) state of chaos / (C) since the / (D) chairman resigned.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 12_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
The sentence "It is a state of chaos since the chairman resigned." contains an error in part A.

Option B, contains the error because the structure of the sentence is incorrect when using "state of chaos" with "since the chairman resigned." The phrase needs a verb form to indicate the duration of the state of chaos. The correct form should use the present perfect tense to convey that the chaos has been ongoing since the chairman resigned.

The corrected sentence should be: "It has been a state of chaos since the chairman resigned."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Had you / not reached in time, / we will have / lost our lives.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 13 August Shift 1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Correct Answer: we will have

Solution:

  • The sentence is a third conditional sentence, which describes an unreal past situation and its imagined result.

  • Structure of third conditional:
    If + past perfect, would have + past participle

  • Correct sentence: "Had you not reached in time, we would have lost our lives."

  • The segment "we will have" is incorrect because "will have" is future tense, but the sentence refers to a past unreal condition, so it should be "would have".

Meanings:
reached – arrived (पहुंचे)
lost our lives – died (हमारी जान चली जाती)
would have – used to show imagined past result (हो गया होता)

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
As twilight settled / upon the bustling city, / its streets come alive with / a symphony of flickering lights.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 13 Oct Shift-1 (9_00 to 11_00 AM))
option_1: its streets come alive with
option_3: a symphony of flickering lights
solution:
Answer: a) its streets come alive with

Explanation:
The sentence is mostly in the past tense, as seen in the phrase “As twilight settled” (past tense verb).

  • However, “its streets come alive with” uses the present tense verb “come”, which creates a tense inconsistency.

  • To maintain consistency, it should be “its streets came alive with” (past tense).

Other segments are grammatically correct:

  • “As twilight settled” – correct past tense

  • “upon the bustling city” – correct prepositional phrase

  • “a symphony of flickering lights” – correct noun phrase

Hence, the error is in segment a) due to the wrong tense of the verb.

question:
Select the option that contains a grammatical error in the underlined portion.
I didn’t sleep well last night because the dog is barking.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 13 Oct Shift-1 (9_00 to 11_00 AM))
option_1: I didn’t s̲l̲e̲e̲p̲ ̲w̲e̲l̲l̲ last night because the dog is barking.
option_2: I didn’t sleep well l̲a̲s̲t̲ ̲n̲i̲g̲h̲t̲ ̲b̲e̲c̲a̲u̲s̲e̲ the dog is barking.
option_3: I didn’t sleep well last night because t̲h̲e̲ ̲d̲o̲g̲ ̲i̲s̲ ̲b̲a̲r̲k̲i̲n̲g̲.
option_4: I̲ ̲d̲i̲d̲n̲’̲t̲ sleep well last night because the dog is barking.
solution:
Answer: c) I didn’t sleep well last night because the dog is barking.

Explanation:
The sentence describes a past event ("didn’t sleep well last night") but incorrectly uses the present continuous tense ("the dog is barking") for the cause.

  • To maintain tense consistency, the verb related to the cause should also be in the past tense or past continuous:
    “because the dog was barking.”

Other options differ only in punctuation or spacing but do not contain a grammatical tense error.

Hence, segment c) contains the error due to tense inconsistency.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
In October, / they will have been lived / in San Francisco /for five years.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 13 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
option_4: they will have been lived
solution:
Answer: they will have been lived

Explanation:
The phrase “they will have been lived” is grammatically incorrect.

  • The correct future perfect continuous tense form should be:
    “they will have been living”
    (will + have + been + present participle)

  • “Lived” is the past participle and does not fit with “been” here.

Other parts are correct:

  • “In October,” – correct time phrase

  • “in San Francisco” – correct place phrase

  • “for five years” – correct duration phrase

Hence, the error is in “they will have been lived.”

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Sheetal always became nervous / whenever she gets instructions / from her Physics / teacher at the lab.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 13 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
solution:
Answer: Sheetal always became nervous

Explanation:
The error is in the tense inconsistency between the main and subordinate clauses.

  • The subordinate clause “whenever she gets instructions” is in present tense.

  • The main clause uses “became”, which is past tense.

  • For consistency, both should be in the same tense.

Either:

  • “Sheetal always becomes nervous whenever she gets instructions” (present tense), or

  • “Sheetal always became nervous whenever she got instructions” (past tense).

Since the subordinate clause is present tense, the correct form should use “becomes” instead of “became.”

Hence, the error lies in “Sheetal always became nervous.”

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Arpit and Barkha went /for Zumba / classes these / days.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 13 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
solution:
Answer: d) Arpit and Barkha went

Explanation:
The error lies in the segment “Arpit and Barkha went” because the sentence lacks the correct tense and completeness to match the phrase “these days.”

  • The phrase “these days” indicates a habitual or repeated action in the present, so the sentence should use the present continuous tense or a similar form:
    ✔ Correct form: “Arpit and Barkha are going for Zumba classes these days.”

  • Using “went” (simple past) does not fit with “these days,” which refers to the current period.

Other segments:

  • “for Zumba” – correct

  • “classes these” – word order is incorrect but the main grammatical issue here is tense

  • “days” – correct

Hence, option (d) is the segment with the grammatical error due to wrong tense for the time expression.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
(1) It is raining / (2) when they played / (3) the cricket match last night. / (4) No error

(SSC Steno 2023 : 13 Oct Shift-3 4_30 PM - 6_30 PM)
solution:
Answer: (2) 1

Explanation:
You are absolutely right — the sentence is referring to a past event (“last night”), so the verb in part (1) should also be in the past tense, not present.

  • “It is raining” (present continuous) is incorrect for a past-time reference.

  • It should be “It was raining” to match the past context of “last night”.

  • ✅ Correct sentence: It was raining when they played the cricket match last night.

Hence, the error lies in part (1).

question:

  • Other parts are grammatically correct.

So, the error is in “takes classes”, and the correct form is “took classes”.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.

solution:

  • But “disposed” is past tense, which is incorrect here.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
The team played / really well, but / they lose the game / in the final minutes.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 13_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
The part that contains the error is: they lose the game

The error is in the verb tense. The past tense "lost" should be used to maintain consistency with the past tense used earlier in the sentence ("played").

The corrected sentence would be: "The team played really well, but they lost the game in the final minutes."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
The availability of funds will be / ensured if they all tried to / submit the proposals on time.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 14 July Shift-4)
option_1: ensured if they all tried to
option_2: The availability of funds will be
option_3: submit the proposals on time
solution:
Answer: ensured if they all tried to

Solution:

  • The error is in the phrase "ensured if they all tried to".

  • The first part of the sentence uses "will be", which is future tense.

  • After "if," the verb should be in the present tense (simple present) to correctly form the conditional sentence.

  • Therefore, "tried" (past tense) is incorrect here; it should be "try" (present tense).

Correct sentence:
"The availability of funds will be ensured if they all try to submit the proposals on time."

So, the error is in part 1: "ensured if they all tried to".

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
My father told me / that in his childhood / he was walking / to school every day.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 14_Sept_Shift_1)
solution:
The segment that contains an error is: "to school every day."

The correct preposition to use in this context is "to," so the corrected segment should be: "to school every day." This phrase indicates the direction of the action (walking) and is commonly used when describing the daily routine of going to a place.

The corrected sentence would be: "My father told me that in his childhood he was walking to school every day."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
When Nisha will have finished her task?

(SSC MTS 2023 : 14_Sept_Shift_1)
solution:
The option that contains an error is: When Nisha will.

The error in the sentence lies in the placement of the auxiliary verb "will." In English, when forming a question with a modal verb like "will," the standard order is to place the modal verb before the subject. So, the auxiliary verb "will" should come before the subject "Nisha" in an interrogative sentence. The structure "When Nisha will have finished her task?" is not grammatically correct in English.

The correct formation would be: "When will Nisha have finished her task?"Top of Form

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
The construction of / the new business school / is led to / a sudden rise of population in our area.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 17 August Shift 2 (12 to 1 PM))
option_4: a sudden rise of population in our area
solution:
Correct Answer: is led to

Solution:
The error lies in the phrase "is led to".
The correct phrase should be "has led to", because the sentence is referring to a present result of a past action — a classic case for using present perfect tense.

Correct sentence:
"The construction of the new business school has led to a sudden rise of population in our area."

Why others are correct:

  • "The construction of" – correct subject phrase.

  • "the new business school" – correct noun phrase.

  • "a sudden rise of population in our area" – grammatically correct, though "in population" would be slightly more natural, it's not incorrect.

Difficult Words and Meanings:
led – past participle of "lead", meaning to cause or result in – कारण बनना
construction – the act of building – निर्माण
population – the number of people living in an area – जनसंख्या

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
She will already return home / when her parents get back / from their offices.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 17 Nov S-1)
option_2: when her parents get back
option_4: She will already return home
solution:
Answer: (a) She will already return home

Explanation:

  • The phrase “She will already return home” is grammatically incorrect.

  • The correct form should be: “She will have already returned home”.

  • We use “will have + past participle” (future perfect tense) to describe an action that will be completed before another future action.

✅ Correct sentence: She will have already returned home when her parents get back from their offices.

So, the error is in part (a).

question:
Identify the option that rectifies the error in the given sentence.
In the future, people are not going to physical stores as much as they do now.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 17 Nov S-1)
option_1: In the future, people were not going to physical stores as much as they do now.
option_2: In the future, people are not gone to physical stores as much as they do now.
option_3: In the future, people should not go to physical stores as much as they do now.
option_4: In the future, people will not go to physical stores as much as they do now.
solution:
Answer: (d) In the future, people will not go to physical stores as much as they do now.

Explanation:

  • The phrase “In the future” requires a future tense verb.

  • The original sentence uses “are not going”, which is present continuous, not suitable for future predictions.

✅ “Will not go” correctly expresses a future action (भविष्य की क्रिया).
Other options:

  • (a) were not going – ❌ past tense

  • (b) are not gone – ❌ grammatically incorrect

  • (c) should not go – ❌ changes the meaning (suggestion, not prediction)

So, the correct version is:
“In the future, people will not go to physical stores as much as they do now.”

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Radha told her friends that / she will discuss the project / with her mentor when / she would meet him tomorrow.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 17 Nov S-1)
solution:
Answer: (b) she would meet him tomorrow.

Explanation:

  • The sentence is in indirect (reported) speech, introduced by the past tense verb “told”.

  • In reported speech, time expressions like “tomorrow” must be changed to “the next day” or “the following day.”

  • Hence, “she would meet him tomorrow” is incorrect.
    It should be: “she would meet him the next day.”

✅ All other segments are grammatically correct.
❌ Segment (d) contains the error due to incorrect use of a time expression in indirect speech.

question:
The given sentence is divided into three segments. Select the option that has the segment with a grammatical error. If there is no error, select 'no error' as your answer.
I miss you / when you move / to another building.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 17 Nov S-2)
solution:
Answer: (c) I miss you

Explanation:

  • The sentence talks about a future event: “when you move to another building.”

  • Therefore, the main verb should be in the future tense to match the time frame.

  • Instead of “I miss you,” it should be “I will miss you.”

  • Using the present tense “I miss you” here is grammatically incorrect because it does not agree with the future context.

Hence, the error lies in segment (c) “I miss you.”

question:

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Nowadays, common people take / interest in the manner / in which / they were governed.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 18 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I fell / asleep while / I read / the book.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 18 July Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: I read
Solution:

  • The sentence is in past tense: "I fell asleep..."

  • The segment "I read" should also be in past continuous to indicate an action that was happening at the time the subject fell asleep.

  • Correct form: "I was reading", not "I read"

  • So, the corrected sentence is: "I fell asleep while I was reading the book."

  • ✅ Therefore, the grammatical error is in: I read.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
By this time tomorrow, / you will be playing / the violin / for 48 hours.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-1)
solution:
Answer: (b) you will be playing

Explanation:

  • The sentence aims to express a future perfect continuous action (playing the violin for 48 hours by a certain time).

  • The correct structure is:
    “By this time tomorrow, you will have been playing the violin for 48 hours.”

  • “You will be playing” (future continuous) is incorrect here because it doesn’t show the duration up to that point.

  • So, the error lies in segment (b) where the tense should be future perfect continuous instead of future continuous.

Hence, option (b) is correct.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
While driving, Satheesh always / switches off his mobile phone / and kept it in the dashboard.

option_2: and kept it in the dashboard
option_3: switches off his mobile phone
solution:
Answer: (b) and kept it in the dashboard

The sentence is in the present habitual tense because of the phrase "always switches off". To maintain consistency, all actions describing habitual behavior should be in the present tense.

  • "Satheesh always switches off his mobile phone" — Present tense, correct.

  • But "and kept it in the dashboard" — Past tense, which is inconsistent.

It should be:
"and keeps it in the dashboard" to maintain present tense consistency.

Other parts are correct:

  • "While driving, Satheesh always" – introductory phrase, no error.

  • "switches off his mobile phone" – present tense, correct.

Hence, the error is in the part: "and kept it in the dashboard".

question:
The given sentence is divided into three segments. Select the option that has the segment with a grammatical error. If there is no error, select 'no error' as your answer.
By next year, / we will been living / in Bengaluru for eight years.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-1)
option_4: in Bengaluru for eight years
solution:
Answer: we will been living

Explanation:
The correct future perfect continuous tense is formed with "will have been", not "will been".
The correct phrase should be:
"we will have been living".

question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error.
Smita lived in this house since she was five years old.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 19 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

The error is in the verb tense used in the segment "Smita lived."

🔸 Rule Involved:

When using “since” with a point in time (e.g., since she was five years old), you must use the Present Perfect or Present Perfect Continuous tense — not the Simple Past.

❌ Incorrect usage:

Smita lived in this house since she was five years old.
(Simple Past is incorrect with “since”) —

✅ Correct usage:

Smita has lived in this house since she was five years old.
(Present Perfect — सही है क्योंकि वह अभी भी वहाँ रह रही है।)

🟩 Evaluation of Other Options:

  • in this house – ✅ Correct phrase, no error. (इस घर में)

  • since she was – ✅ Correct usage of “since” to denote starting point in the past. (जबसे वह थी)

  • five years old – ✅ Grammatically fine. (पाँच साल की थी)

✅ Final Answer: Smita lived
